bibl.title: Letter from Blossom Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, March 28, 1952

div1.p: Blossom Reed describes her financial problems in trying to keep her home. She explains to Hench that she will not supply information about Susie to Clark because she hopes to have Susie's story published for her own financial gain.

div1.head: Letter from Blossom Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, March 28, 1952
div1.opener:
March '28- 52-
MRS. BLOSSOM REED
BLUE RIDGE SUMMIT
PENNSYLVANIA
Dear Dr- Hench-
div1.p:
Your letter
came the day
I went to Washington
to see the family-
I am very sorry
to say - that I am
not going to write
to Mr- Clark from
William and Mary
College - for I am
making a “stab” to
maintain my home
here - and have
gotten some one
to start a story on
the “Indian woman”
Mr- Clark wrote you
about- I am hoping
it may be published
in due time- I
opened my home
here - feeling I
could see the
MRS. BLOSSOM REED
BLUE RIDGE SUMMIT
PENNSYLVANIA
winter through, as
time piercing here
was to bring so
many people to us
here- Congress
thought another
way - appropritations
were cut - men
& their families had
to leave who came
to work - and
I got one couple
in my apt I have on the 2nd floor - for
7500 a month -
with heat lights etc
etc furnished by me-
and with the 8400
Walter Reed Mem-
sends me- I turned
& twisted to make
ends meet- But
I've “drained the
larder” now - and
so this story- Pray
for me that it
MRS. BLOSSOM REED
BLUE RIDGE SUMMIT
PENNSYLVANIA
may help me keep
my head above
water - till I get
some people in
my home - and
now I wont take
any more of your
time- But I am
very truthful as
you know about
my life-
Ac
R
I hope you and
your dear family
are well - We
speak of you so
much when I
go to Brother's
and of how wonderful
you have been-

With best wishes
and love to your
wife-
